tit.e: Misodengaku (skewed and roasted foodstuff with miso coating)
tit.cmt: カッコ部分を補いました。
tit.e: Misodengaku (skewed and roasted foodstuff with miso coating)

sen.j: 味噌田楽（みそでんがく）とは、豆腐やこんにゃく、ナスやサトイモなどを串に刺し、ユズやサンショウなどで香りをつけた味噌を塗りつけて焼いた料理。
sen.e: "Misodengaku" is a dish prepared by skewering foodstuffs such as tofu, konjac, egg plant and satoimo (taro), coating them with Japanese-lemon (citron) or Japanese-pepper flavored miso (bean paste) and then roasting them.

"Misodengaku" is a dish prepared by skewering foodstuffs such as tofu, konnyaku, egg plant and satoimo (taro), pasting them with Japanese-lemon (citron) or Japanese-pepper flavored miso (bean paste) and then roasting them.
sen.cmt: konjac→konnyaku と修正しました。（ヘボン式）coating→pasting と修正しました。
sen.e: "Misodengaku" is a dish prepared by skewering foodstuffs such as tofu, konnyaku, egg plant and satoimo (taro), pasting them with Japanese-lemon (citron) or Japanese-pepper flavored miso (bean paste) and then roasting them.
Origin of Name
Origin of Name
Origin of Name

sen.j: 語源はその具を串刺しにした格好が、田楽のひとつである、田んぼに棒を突き立てその上で踊る「高足の舞」に似ている事から名づけられたと言われる。
sen.e: The name is said to have been derived from one of Dengaku (style of dancing and music originally performed at agricultural festivals) pieces, "Takaashi-no-mai" (dance on high legs), since the shape of skewered foodstuffs looked like the dance performed on poles put up on the rice field.

The name is said to have been derived from one of the Dengaku (style of dancing and music originally performed at agricultural festivals) pieces, "Takaashi-no-mai" (dance on high legs), since the shape of skewered foodstuffs looked like the dance performed on poles put up on the rice field.
sen.cmt: the を挿入しました。スペースを修正しました。
sen.e: The name is said to have been derived from one of the Dengaku (style of dancing and music originally performed at agricultural festivals) pieces, "Takaashi-no-mai" (dance on high legs), since the shape of skewered foodstuffs looked like the dance performed on poles put up on the rice field.

sen.j: また、桶狭間の合戦の際、織田方に敗れた今川方が磔（はりつけ）などによって処刑された地が「田楽窪」（でんがくがくぼ）と呼ばれる、かつて古典芸能の田楽が行われていたのではないかと言われる地（現在も愛知県豊明市沓掛町内に大字名として残る）で、その処刑方法が当時当地で食されていた野菜や鮎などの川魚を串に刺して食していたものと似ていたため、それを田楽と呼んだという説もある。
sen.e: Another theory is that at a place called "Dengakukubo" (in Kutsukake-cho Toyoake City Aichi Prefecture, and the name of the place "Dengakukubo" has survived to remain used in the address), where one of Japanese classic popular performing arts, Dengaku, is said to have been played, the Imagawa defeated in the Battle of Okehazama were crucified, and local residents around there began to call vegetables and freshwater fishes such as ayu (sweetfish, Plecoglossus altivelis altivelis) on skewers they used to eat "Dengaku", associating the crucification method conducted there with the cooking method.

Another theory is that at a place called "Dengakukubo" (in Kutsukake-cho, Toyoake City, Aichi Prefecture, and the name of the place "Dengakukubo" has survived to remain used in the address today), where one of Japanese classic popular performing arts, Dengaku, is said to have been played, the Imagawa side defeated by Oda side in the Battle of Okehazama were crucified, and the local residents around there began to call vegetables and freshwater fishes such as ayu (sweetfish, Plecoglossus altivelis altivelis) on skewers they used to eat "Dengaku," associating the crucification method conducted there with the cooking method.
sen.cmt: カンマを挿入しました。「現在も」「織田方」を補いました。スペース、カンマの位置の修正をしました。side を補いました。
sen.e: Another theory is that at a place called "Dengakukubo" (in Kutsukake-cho, Toyoake City, Aichi Prefecture, and the name of the place "Dengakukubo" has survived to remain used in the address today), where one of Japanese classic popular performing arts, Dengaku, is said to have been played, the Imagawa side defeated by Oda side in the Battle of Okehazama were crucified, and the local residents around there began to call vegetables and freshwater fishes such as ayu (sweetfish, Plecoglossus altivelis altivelis) on skewers they used to eat "Dengaku," associating the crucification method conducted there with the cooking method.
Senryu (comic haiku)
Senryu (comic haiku)
Senryu (comic haiku)

sen.j: 成り立ちを伺い知ることができる古川柳が、今も残っている。
sen.e: The following old senryu poem has survived to tell us about the history of Dengaku.
The following old senryu poem has survived to tell us about the origin of Dengaku.
The following old senryu poem has survived to tell us about the origin of Dengaku.

sen.j: 「田楽は昔は目で見今は食ひ」
sen.e: Dengaku wa Mukashi wa me de mite Ima wa kui (meaning "Dengaku, in ancient days to look at,while today to eat")
Dengaku wa Mukashi wa me de mite Ima wa kui (meaning 'Dengaku, in ancient days to look at,while today to eat')
sen.cmt: 引用符を修正しました。
sen.e: Dengaku wa Mukashi wa me de mite Ima wa kui (meaning 'Dengaku, in ancient days to look at,while today to eat')
Types
Types
Types

sen.j: 愛知県豊橋市の「なめし田楽」は、八丁味噌の豆腐の田楽と菜飯をセットにしたものである。
sen.e: "Nameshi dengaku"of Toyohashi City Aichi Prefecture is a combination of tofu dengaku using haccho miso (bean paste produced at Okazaki City Aichi Prefecture) and a bowl of nameshi (rice to which some green vegetable are added).
sen.cmt: 八丁味噌の説明を追加しました。
sen.e: "Nameshi dengaku"of Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture is a combination of tofu dengaku using haccho miso (bean paste produced at Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture) and a bowl of nameshi (rice to which some green vegetable are added).
sen.cmt: F欄にあったコメントをE欄に移動しました。カンマを挿入しました。
sen.e: "Nameshi dengaku"of Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture is a combination of tofu dengaku using haccho miso (bean paste produced at Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture) and a bowl of nameshi (rice to which some green vegetable are added).

sen.j: この「菜飯田楽」は東海道五十三次の吉田宿（豊橋市）の名物料理のひとつであったと言う。
sen.e: Nameshi dengaku is said to have been one of the famous food menus at Yoshida-juku Station (Toyohashi City Aichi Prefecture), one of Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi (the fifty-three stations of the Tokaido Road).

Nameshi dengaku' is said to have been one of the famous food at Yoshida-juku Station (Toyohashi City Aichi Prefecture), one of the Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi (the fifty-three stations of the Tokaido Road).
sen.cmt: 引用符を挿入しました。menus を削除しました。the を補いました。
sen.e: Nameshi dengaku' is said to have been one of the famous food at Yoshida-juku Station (Toyohashi City Aichi Prefecture), one of the Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi (the fifty-three stations of the Tokaido Road).

sen.j: また同じ愛知県の津島市には、尾張地方中南部の名物でもある生麩を揚げて赤味噌を塗った「麩田楽」がある。
sen.e: "Fudengaku", which is prepared by frying nama-fu (fresh gluten cake), a famous product of the mid-southern part of Owari region, and coating it with red miso, is included in the local cuisine of Tsushima City in the same prefecture.

Also, "Fudengaku," which is prepared by frying nama-fu (fresh gluten cake), a famous product of the mid-southern part of Owari region, and coating it with red miso, is included in the local cuisine of Tsushima City in Aichi Prefecture.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を修正しました。in the same prefecture→Aichi Prefecture と修正しました。
sen.e: Also, "Fudengaku," which is prepared by frying nama-fu (fresh gluten cake), a famous product of the mid-southern part of Owari region, and coating it with red miso, is included in the local cuisine of Tsushima City in Aichi Prefecture.
Notes
Notes
Notes

sen.j: 現在では事実上の豆腐料理になっている場合が多いが、山間部などでは現在でもサトイモや川魚を主体にした串焼きに近い田楽が供されている地域も多い。
sen.e: Today, most misodengaku dishes are actually prepared by using tofu while in many mountainous areas, dengaku is prepared mainly by using satoimo or freshfish on skewers like "kushiyaki" (grilled skewered foods).

Today, most misodengaku dishes are actually prepared by using tofu, while in many mountainous areas, dengaku is prepared mainly by using satoimo or freshwater fish on skewers, similar to "kushiyaki" (grilled skewered foods).
sen.cmt: カンマを挿入しました。freshfish→freshwater fish,like→similar to と修正しました。
sen.e: Today, most misodengaku dishes are actually prepared by using tofu, while in many mountainous areas, dengaku is prepared mainly by using satoimo or freshwater fish on skewers, similar to "kushiyaki" (grilled skewered foods).

sen.j: 「おでん」は田楽の材料を焼く替りに煮た、「煮込み田楽」に由来する料理である。
sen.e: "Oden" is a dish originating from "Nikomidengaku" in which ingredients used for dengaku are boiled instead of roasting.
"Oden" is a dish originating from "Nikomidengaku," in which ingredients used for dengaku are boiled instead of roasting.
sen.cmt: カンマを挿入しました。
sen.e: "Oden" is a dish originating from "Nikomidengaku," in which ingredients used for dengaku are boiled instead of roasting.
